traits.name: Arachnid Build
traits.description:
You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push or drag, and you have advantage on saving throws against being knocked prone.

In addition, you have a climbing speed equal to your walking speed. In addition, at 3rd level, you can move up, down, and across vertical surfaces and upside down along ceilings, while leaving your hands free.

If you hit with them, you deal slashing damage equal to 1d6 + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

traits.name: Writhing Arms
traits.description: In place of your arms, you have masses of writing snakes. You have advantage on ability checks and saving throws against being disarmed, and you have a climbing speed equal to your walking speed.

arcane-shot.name: Banishing Shot
arcane-shot.description: You use abjuration magic to try to temporarily banish your target to a harmless location in the Feywild. The creature hit by the shot takes extra force damage equal to your Exploit Die and must also succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be banished. While banished in this way, its speed is 0, and it is incapacitated. At the end of its next turn, the target reappears in the space it vacated or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied.

arcane-shot.name: Beguiling Shot
arcane-shot.description: Your enchantment magic causes this shot to temporarily beguile its target. The creature hit by the shot takes extra psychic damage equal to twice your Exploit Die, and choose one of your allies within 30 feet of the target. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw, or it is charmed by the chosen ally until the start of your next turn. This effect ends early if the chosen ally attacks the charmed target, deals damage to it, or forces it to make a saving throw.

arcane-shot.name: Bursting Shot
arcane-shot.description: You imbue your shot with force energy drawn from the school of evocation. The shot detonates after your attack. Immediately after the shot hits the creature, the target and all other creatures within 10 feet of it take force damage equal to twice your Exploit Die each.

arcane-shot.name: Draining Shot
arcane-shot.description: You weave restorative magic into your shot. The creature hit by the shot takes extra piercing damage equal to twice your Exploit Die and a creature of your choice within 30 feet of the target regains hit points equal to the extra damage dealt.

arcane-shot.name: Enfeebling Shot
arcane-shot.description: You weave necromantic magic into your shot. The creature hit by the shot takes extra necrotic damage equal to twice your Exploit Die. The target must also succeed on a Constitution saving throw, or the damage dealt by its weapon attacks is halved until the start of your next turn.

arcane-shot.name: Grasping Shot
arcane-shot.description: When this shot strikes its target, conjuration magic creates grasping, poisonous brambles, which wrap around the target. The creature hit by the shot takes extra poison damage equal to twice your Exploit Die, its speed is reduced by 10 feet, and it takes the damage again the first time on each turn it moves 1 foot or more without teleporting. The target or any creature that can reach it can use its action to remove the brambles with a successful Strength (Athletics) check against your Arcane Shot save DC. Otherwise, the brambles last for 1 minute or until you use this option again.

arcane-shot.name: Piercing Shot
arcane-shot.description: You use transmutation magic to give your shot an ethereal quality. When you use this option, you don't make an attack roll for the attack. Instead, the shot fires forward in a line, which is 1 foot wide and 30 feet long, before disappearing. The shot passes harmlessly through objects, ignoring cover. Each creature in that line must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes damage as if it were hit by the shot, plus extra piercing damage equal to your Exploit Die. On a successful save, a target takes half as much damage.

arcane-shot.name: Seeking Shot
arcane-shot.description: Using divination magic, you grant your shot the ability to seek out your target, allowing the shot to curve and twist its path in search of its prey. When you use this option, you don't make an attack roll for the attack. Instead, choose one creature you have seen in the past minute. The shot flies toward that creature, moving around corners if necessary and ignoring three-quarters cover and half cover. If the target is within the weapon's range and there is a path large enough for the shot to travel to the target, the target must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, it takes damage as if it were hit by the shot, plus extra force damage equal to your Exploit Die, and you learn the target's current location. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage, and you don't learn its location.

arcane-shot.name: Shadow Shot
arcane-shot.description: You weave illusion magic into your shot, causing it to occlude your foe's vision with shadows. The creature hit by the shot takes extra psychic damage equal to twice your Exploit Die, and it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be unable to see anything farther than 5 feet away until the start of your next turn.

arcane-shot.name: Teleporting Shot
arcane-shot.description: You weave transposition magic into your shot, causing it to teleport the target against their will. The creature hit by the shot takes extra force damage equal to twice your Exploit Die, and it must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be teleported to an unoccupied space of your choice within 30 feet of it.

astounding-power.name: Aftershock
astounding-power.description: You can cast Thunderwave by striking the ground at your feet, using Strength as your spellcasting ability, and without using verbal components. The spell's level equals your proficiency bonus. Once you use this power, you must complete a long rest before using it again. In addition, nonmagical, unprotected flames within the spell's area of effect are put out.

astounding-power.name: Anatomical Armor
astounding-power.description: While you are not wearing armor, your Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Constitution modifier. You can use your Anatomical Armor to determine your AC if the armor you are wearing would leave you with less AC.

astounding-power.name: Arcane Synesthesia
astounding-power.description: You can cast Detect Magic at will, without using components.

astounding-power.name: Barehanded Block
astounding-power.description: If a creature hits you with a melee attack while you are unarmed, unarmored, and are not wielding a shield, you can use your reaction to add your proficiency bonus to your AC for that attack, potentially causing the attack to miss you.

astounding-power.name: Boring Monologue
astounding-power.description: You can cast Charm Person as a 1st level spell, using Charisma as your spellcasting ability. Rather than viewing you as a friendly acquaintance on a failed save, the target will admit that they are swayed by your reasonable line of thinking. Once you use this power, you must complete a short or long rest to use it again.

astounding-power.name: Collateral Damage
astounding-power.description: You are proficient in the use of improvised weapons, and you can make use of your Pure Strength feature while wielding an improvised weapon.

astounding-power.name: Courage
astounding-power.description: You regain a use of Strength Surge when you score a critical hit with an unarmed strike.

astounding-power.name: Destiny
astounding-power.description: You can cast Augury without using material components or expending spell slots. Once you use this power, you must complete a long rest to do so again.

astounding-power.name: Daredevil
astounding-power.description: You gain 15 feet of Tremorsense, and 5 feet of Blindsight.

astounding-power.name: Fan Club
astounding-power.description:
Whenever you interact with a non-hostile NPC for the first time, the DM must roll a d20. On a roll of 20, the NPC recognizes you and is a fan of your exploits, and you have advantage on all Charisma checks against them until they have a reason to dislike you.

Members of your Fan Club cannot recognize you while you are using your Secret Identity. However, they can still recognize you even if you have the Nameless power, as they have been theorizing that your death was a hoax.

astounding-power.name: Harrowing Vision
astounding-power.description: You can see normally in darkness, both magical and non magical, to a distance of 120 feet.

astounding-power.name: Immortal Spirit
astounding-power.description: When you dream or meditate, you can access the memories of empowered beings that came before you. The DM rolls a d20 to determine the quality of the visions you receive, ranging from vague symbolism on a roll of 1, to crucial information on a roll of 20. At the DM's discretion, you might receive visions from one empowered being in particular, and that being might even speak to you directly.

astounding-power.name: Keen Vision
astounding-power.description: With clear visibility, you can make out details of extremely distant creatures and objects as small as 2 feet across.

astounding-power.name: Momentus Tackle
astounding-power.description: When you use a bonus action to attempt to grapple or shove a creature, you have an additional 10 feet of movement that you can use exclusively to get close enough to your desired target.

astounding-power.name: Nameless
astounding-power.description: When you gain this power, you toss your old identity aside, allowing you to choose a new name and alignment. The old you is presumed dead by those who are not adventuring with you, and you won't be hunted down for crimes the old you committed. If a creature that used to know you discovers that you are not dead, they become stunned until the end of your next turn. You revert to your old identity permanently if you swap this power out for a new one.

astounding-power.name: Persona (Detective)
astounding-power.description: You gain proficiency in the Investigation and Perception skills.

astounding-power.name: Persona (Dramatic)
astounding-power.description: You can cast the Thaumaturgy cantrip, and gain proficiency in Performance.

astounding-power.name: Persona (Heroic)
astounding-power.description: You gain proficiency in the Insight and Persuasion skills.

astounding-power.name: Persona (Mysterious)
astounding-power.description: You gain proficiency in the Stealth and Survival skills.

astounding-power.name: Persona (Villainous)
astounding-power.description: You gain proficiency in the Deception and Intimidation skills.

astounding-power.name: Plot Armor
astounding-power.description: When you roll a 1 on a d20 for an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll. Once you use this power, you must complete a short or long rest to use it again.

astounding-power.name: Pure of Heart
astounding-power.description: You are immune to the charmed and dominated conditions.

astounding-power.name: Quipping Expertise
astounding-power.description: You can cast Vicious Mockery, using Charisma as your spellcasting ability. When a creature fails the saving throw you impose with this spell, it has disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes before the end of its next turn.

astounding-power.name: Rending Strength
astounding-power.description: You can expend a use of Strength Surge as an action to crush, bend, or break an inanimate object within your reach that is made of non-magical materials and is not being worn or carried. For larger objects, the area of the object that is bent, broken, or crushed is no larger than a 3-foot cube.

astounding-power.name: Secret Identity
astounding-power.description:
You have an alter ego: a more mundane identity that you use outside of your adventuring life. Your alter ego has a separate name, home, occupation, and perhaps even a family or a place amongst high society. You can adopt this alternate identity as a disguise, and other creatures believe you to be that person until given an obvious reason not to.

Inexplicably, you can don or doff your alter ego in the blink of an eye, but only when no one is watching.

astounding-power.name: Sidekick
astounding-power.description:
As an action, you can designate one friendly creature as your sidekick. While you and your sidekick are within 10 feet of one another, each of you can use a reaction to take half of an instance of damage dealt to the other.

Once you choose your sidekick, you cannot choose a new one until you complete a long rest. You can only have one sidekick at a time, so choosing a new sidekick removes the effects of this power from your previous sidekick.

astounding-power.name: Suplex
astounding-power.description: When you hit a creature you are grappling with an unarmed strike using Pure Strength, you can move them to the space directly behind you if it is unoccupied, and knock them prone. The creature receives the strike's damage after they are knocked prone.

astounding-power.name: Unyielding
astounding-power.description: You can cast the Heroism spell on yourself without using components, using Constitution as your spellcasting ability. Once you use this power, you must complete a long rest to use it again.

astounding-power.name: Valiant Soul
astounding-power.description: You are immune to the frightened condition.

astounding-power.name: Wham!
astounding-power.description: When you score a critical hit with an unarmed strike using Pure Strength, and the target is not prone, you can push the creature back 15 feet and knock them prone.

astounding-power.name: Wild Leap
astounding-power.description: Your jump distance is increased by 5 feet when you make a running long or high jump. You only need to run 5 feet to make a running long or high jump.

astounding-power.name: Yield
astounding-power.description: You can cast Command as a 1st level spell, using Charisma as your spellcasting ability. Once you use this power, you cannot use it again until you complete a short or long rest.

astounding-power.name: Aquatic Nature
astounding-power.description: You gain 30 feet of swimming speed, and you can breathe underwater. Additionally, you can communicate with creatures that have an innate swimming speed.

astounding-power.name: Cling Grip
astounding-power.description: While you are not wearing heavy armor, you gain 30 feet of climbing speed. You also gain the ability to move up, down, and across vertical surfaces and upside down along ceilings, while leaving your hands free.

astounding-power.name: Laser Eyes
astounding-power.description: You can cast Scorching Ray from your eyes using Constitution as your spellcasting ability and without using components. The spell's level is equal to your proficiency bonus. The spell deals infusion damage if you chose the Conduit Manifestation. Once you use this power, you must complete a long rest to use it again.

astounding-power.name: Shockwave
astounding-power.description: As an action on your turn, you can create a shockwave in front of you by punching the air. Creatures in a 15 foot cone in front of you must make a Dexterity saving throw against your power save DC to avoid being knocked prone.

astounding-power.name: Violence
astounding-power.description: Whenever you roll a 1 or 2 on your Pure Strength die, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2.

astounding-power.name: Wolven-Claw
astounding-power.description: You can grow claws from your fingertips or between your knuckles as a bonus action. For 1 minute, you gain a bonus to damage rolls for your unarmed strikes made using Pure Strength equal to your proficiency bonus, and your unarmed strikes deal slashing damage. Once you use this power, you must complete a short or long rest to use it again.

astounding-power.name: Flight
astounding-power.description: You gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed.

astounding-power.name: Launching Maneuver
astounding-power.description: You can expend a use of Strength Surge as a bonus action to propel yourself a number of feet equal to 10 times your proficiency bonus in any direction, leaving a small crater where you were standing. This movement ends early if you impact an obstruction. If you impact a creature, you can attempt to grapple them as part of the same bonus action.

astounding-power.name: Perfect Landing
astounding-power.description: You can use your reaction when you fall to reduce any falling damage you take by an amount equal to five times your empowered level.

astounding-power.name: Vitreous Form
astounding-power.description: When you are in an area of dim light or darkness, you can use your action to become invisible until you move or take an action or a reaction.

astounding-power.name: X-Ray Vision
astounding-power.description: As an action, you gain the ability to see through solid objects to a range of 30 feet. Within that range, you have darkvision if you don't already have it. This special sight lasts for 1 minute or until your concentration ends (as if you were concentrating on a spell). During that time, you perceive objects as ghostly, transparent images. Once you use this power, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

astounding-power.name: Fixation
astounding-power.description: You can fixate your willful intent on a creature you can see within 30 feet of you as a bonus action. For 1 minute, so long as you do not damage creatures other than the target, you resist bludgeoning, slashing, and piercing damage from the target. Once you use this power, you must complete a short or long rest to use it again.

astounding-power.name: Immovable Object
astounding-power.description:
You can expend a use of Strength Surge to concentrate on this power as an action (as if concentrating on a spell). While you maintain concentration and do not move, you cannot be moved against your will by creatures no more than one size larger than you.

When an Empowered using Unstoppable Force pushes an Empowered that is using Immovable Object, both lose concentration and they both take 8d8 force damage.

astounding-power.name: Noble Sacrifice
astounding-power.description: Whenever you start your turn with 0 hit points, you can choose a creature that can see you within 30 feet of you. That creature gains Inspiration. Once you use this power, you must complete a long rest to use it again.

astounding-power.name: Stopping Power
astounding-power.description: You can expend a use of Strength Surge as a bonus action to become able to grapple or shove creatures of any size for 1 minute. You cannot move while grappling a creature that is two or more sizes larger than you.

astounding-power.name: Tireless
astounding-power.description: Whenever you finish a short rest, your exhaustion level, if any, is decreased by 1.

astounding-power.name: Clothesline
astounding-power.description: If a creature within 5 feet of you misses you with an attack, you can use a reaction to attempt to grapple or shove them.

astounding-power.name: Healing Factor
astounding-power.description:
So long as you have 1 hit point, you regain hit points equal to a roll of your Pure Strength die at the end of every hour that you spend outside of combat.

Additionally, if you lose a body part, it will grow back and return to full functionality after 1d6 + 1 days if you have at least 1 hit point the whole time.

astounding-power.name: Maximum Effort
astounding-power.description: When you expend your last use of Strength Surge, you can make a DC 10 Strength saving throw. On a successful save, you regain a use of Strength Surge. Each time you use this feature after the first, the DC increases by 5. When you finish a short or long rest, the DC resets to 10.

astounding-power.name: Pure Smite
astounding-power.description: Whenever you land an unarmed strike using Pure Strength, you can expend as many uses of Strength Surge as you like, with each expended use increasing the strike's damage by one roll of your Pure Strength die.

astounding-power.name: Unbreakable
astounding-power.description: You gain resistance to one damage type of your choice.

astounding-power.name: Unstoppable Force
astounding-power.description:
You can expend a use of Strength Surge to concentrate on this power as an action (as if concentrating on a spell). While you maintain concentration, your movement speed cannot be reduced unless you are incapacitated or killed.

This power does not allow you to walk through obvious obstructions, but it does allow you to push creatures no more than one size larger than you 5 feet away just by walking into them. It also prevents you from being grappled, restrained, or affected by difficult terrain. You can only push the same creature once during each of your turns with this power.

When an Empowered using Unstoppable Force pushes an Empowered that is using Immovable Object, both lose concentration and they both take 8d8 force damage.

astounding-power.name: Dormant Energy
astounding-power.description: Whenever you roll for initiative, your Energy Beam automatically becomes charged.

astounding-power.name: Zehpyr Ray
astounding-power.description: Your Energy Beam ignores resistance to your infusion damage type. In addition, when you roll damage for your Energy Beam, you can treat any 1 on a damage die as a 2. This also affects your Hyper Beam once you reach 17th level in this class.

astounding-power.name: Kilojoule
astounding-power.description:
You gain an additional infusion damage type. If your infusion damage is fire, this new damage type is radiant damage. If your infusion damage is cold, this new damage type is necrotic damage. If your infusion damage is lightning, this new damage type is thunder damage.

Alternatively, you can choose an additional one of the three base infusion damage types (fire, cold, or lightning) to be your second infusion damage type.

traits.description: You gain an additional damage type determined by your original damage type.
Your secondary infusion damage type is necrotic.
Your secondary infusion damage type is radiant.
Your infusion damage type is thunder.
You gain an additional damage type from one of the three base types.
Your secondary infusion damage type is cold.
Your secondary infusion damage type is fire.
Your secondary infusion damage type is lightning.

astounding-power.name: Mentalism
astounding-power.description: You can cast Detect Thoughts without using components, using Intelligence as your spellcasting ability. Once you use this power, you must complete a long rest to use it again.

astounding-power.name: Mindseeker
astounding-power.description: You can now use your Intellect Radar as a bonus action on your turn.

astounding-power.name: Instinctive Reflexes
astounding-power.description: Other creatures don't gain advantage on attack rolls against you as a result of being unseen by you. Additionally, you can cast the Find Traps spell. Once you use this power to cast Find Traps, you must complete a short or long rest to do so again.

astounding-power.name: Tunneler
astounding-power.description: You gain 5 feet of burrowing speed, allowing you to dig 5 foot diameter tunnels through sand, earth, mud, or ice. You can't burrow through solid rock or metal.

astounding-power.name: Guiding Hand
astounding-power.description: You can cast Guidance, Reassurance, and Resistance, but only on targets other than yourself.

astounding-power.name: Zeal
astounding-power.description: Whenever you embolden a creature with your Exemplar ability, they gain temporary hit points equal to a roll of your Pure Strength die.

astounding-power.name: Inspired Charge
astounding-power.description: Creatures can take the Dash action as a bonus action on their turn while emboldened by your Exemplar ability. Once they use their bonus action to do so, they cease to be emboldened.

astounding-power.name: Rotten Shell
astounding-power.description: Your unarmed strike can deal acid, poison, or necrotic damage instead of its normal damage type.

astounding-power.name: Grotesque
astounding-power.description: When you use your Monstrous Imitation on a creature, they must make a Wisdom saving throw against your power save DC. On a failed save, the creature is frightened by you for 1 minute. On a successful save, they are frightened by you until the end of your next turn.

astounding-power.name: Bullet-Time
astounding-power.description: Using your Super Speed causes ranged attacks targeting you to be made with disadvantage until the start of your next turn.

astounding-power.name: Lighter Than Air
astounding-power.description: You gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during your move.

astounding-power.name: Thrill of Battle
astounding-power.description: When you roll for initiative, you gain temporary hit points equal to your empowered level.

astounding-power.name: Thousand-Yard Stare
astounding-power.description: You can't be surprised while you are conscious. Additionally, if a creature knows what you want from them, you can make a Charisma (Intimidation) check against them with advantage simply by maintaining prolonged eye-contact with them.

astounding-power.name: Juggernaut
astounding-power.description: You count as a mount while you are in your True Form, allowing your allies to ride on your back.

astounding-power.name: Tantrum
astounding-power.description: If you enter your True Form with no uses of Strength Surge remaining, you regain a single use of Strength Surge.

astounding-power.name: Equipment Expert
astounding-power.description: You gain proficiency with Thieves' Tools if you don't have it already, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with them.

astounding-power.name: Ninjitsu
astounding-power.description: Empowered abilities that apply to your unarmed strikes made using Pure Strength also apply to any attack you make with a simple or martial weapon that lacks the Heavy or Special properties, or a weapon with the Kensei property, so long as you use Strength as the ability modifier for the attack.

artisanal-mask.name: Aristocratic Mask
artisanal-mask.description:
A mask designed to replicate the look of a noble lord or lady, often crafted with ostentatious and luxurious materials.

While wearing this mask, you have advantage on Charisma checks you make towards common folk, so long as they are indifferent or friendly towards you and your allies. In addition, creatures will believe you to be a member of the nobility unless you give them a reason to think otherwise.

subFeatures.name: Greater
subFeatures.description:
As a bonus action on your turn you can grant one creature that can hear you temporary hit points equal to one roll of your Bardic Inspiration die + your spellcasting ability modifier.

If you grant these temporary hit points to another creature, any previous temporary hit points from this feature dispel.

subFeatures.name: Masterwork
subFeatures.description: As a bonus action on your turn you can order a willing creature within 30 feet that can hear an understand you to move 30 feet without provoking opportunity attacks.

artisanal-mask.name: Barbaric Mask
artisanal-mask.description:
A mask created to resemble a wild warrior or beast of the wilderness, often crafted with raw, crude natural materials.

When you don this mask, your current hit points and hit point maximum are increased by an amount equal to your Bard level. In addition, you gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from all nonmagical attacks.

subFeatures.name: Greater
subFeatures.description: When you take the Attack action on your turn you can make two attacks as part of that same Attack action.

subFeatures.name: Masterwork
subFeatures.description: When you hit a target with a melee weapon attack you deal additional damage equal to one roll of your Bardic Inspiration die on hit.

artisanal-mask.name: Devious Mask
artisanal-mask.description:
A mask crafted to resemble a common criminal or thief, often crafted with dark materials and including a hood or cowl.

While wearing this mask, you can use a bonus action to take the Hide, Disengage, or Use and Object actions, and when you make a Dexterity check, you gain a bonus to your roll equal to one roll of your Bardic Inspiration die.

subFeatures.name: Greater
subFeatures.description: When a creature you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the amount of damage that you would have taken from that attack.

subFeatures.name: Masterwork
subFeatures.description: Whenever you make a Dexterity saving throw, you gain a bonus to your roll equal to one roll of your Bardic Inspiraiton die.

artisanal-mask.name: Knightly Mask
artisanal-mask.description:
This mask is crafted to resemble an armored paragon of chivalry, and is often polished to a shine in the sunlight.

While wearing this mask, you are proficient with martial weapons and you gain a +2 bonus to your Armor Class.

In addition, once per turn when you hit a Large or smaller creature with a melee weapon attack you can force it to make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature is knocked prone, knocked back 10 feet in a straight line, or must drop on object it is holding.

subFeatures.name: Greater
subFeatures.description: When you take the Attack action on your turn you can make two attacks as part of that same Attack action.

subFeatures.name: Masterwork
subFeatures.description:
When a creature that you can see targets you with an attack, you can use a reaction to add one roll of your Bardic Inspiration die to your Armor Class against the attack.

If the attack misses, you can make a single melee weapon attack against that creature as part of the same reaction.

artisanal-mask.name: Priestly Mask
artisanal-mask.description:
This mask is crafted to resemble a prophet, saint, or other holy person, often made from delicate yet beautiful materials.

While wearing this Mask, you can use your bonus action to expend a Bardic Inspiration die to restore hit points to one creature that can hear you within 30 feet equal to one roll of your Bardic Inspiration die. In addition, when you restore hit points, or grant temporary hit points to a creature, you add your spellcasting ability modifier to the number of hit points (or temporary hit points) granted.

subFeatures.name: Greater
subFeatures.description: When you damage a creature with a spell or a weapon attack, you can expend a use of Bardic Inspiration to deal radiant damage in place of the normal damage type.

subFeatures.name: Masterwork
subFeatures.description:
As an action, you can touch a creature that has died within the last minute, expend a Bardic Inspiration die, and restore that creature to life with 1 hit point.

However, any creature restored to life in this way gains one level of exhaustion.

artisanal-mask.name: Scholarly Mask
artisanal-mask.description:
This mask is crafted to resemble a distinguished humanoid deep in thought, often crafted from rare and esoteric materials.

While you are wearing this Mask, you gain a bonus to any Intelligence ability checks or saving throws equal to one roll of your Bardic Inspiration die. In addition, when you deal damage to a creature with a weapon attack you learn one of the following characteristics about that creature of your choice: its Armor Class, highest ability score, lowest ability score, or its spellcasting ability.

subFeatures.name: Greater
subFeatures.description: While wearing this Mask you can speak, read, and write all languages, and you can treat a roll of 7 or lower on the d20 for any Intelligence ability check as an 8.

subFeatures.name: Masterwork
subFeatures.description: If you spend 1 hour examining one place, creature, or object, you learn one fact about it as if you had cast the legend lore spell. However, the target need not be of legendary importance for you to learn something.

artisanal-mask.name: Virtuoso Mask
artisanal-mask.description:
This mask is created to resemble a great performer at home on the stage, often crafted to draw attention and stand out.

When you make a Charisma (Performance) or a musical instrument check while you are wearing this Mask you gain a bonus to the roll equal to a roll of your Bardic Inspiration die. In addition, whenever you perform or play an instrument for a creature for at least 1 minute, you have advantage on ability checks you make to influence, interact, or gather information on that creature for the next hour.

subFeatures.name: Greater
subFeatures.description: When you cast a spell with a verbal component while holding a musical instrument, the range of that spell is doubled. Spells with a range of touch gains a range of 30 feet.

subFeatures.name: Masterwork
subFeatures.description: Whenever you perform or play an instrument for a creature for at least 1 minute, it is charmed for 1 hour, or until you damage it or force it to make a saving throw.

bg-feature.name: Abnormal Demeanor
bg-feature.description:
You were raised by monsters of some sort. Work with your GM to determine what raised you and what changes this has upon your personality and mannerisms. Your time with your adopted parents taught you an entire lexicon of habits, behaviors, and intuitions suited to life in the wild among creatures of your parents' type. When you are in the same type of terrain your adopted parent inhabits, you can find food and fresh water for yourself and up to five other people each day.

In addition, when you encounter a creature like your adopted parent or parents, the creature is disposed to hear your words instead of leaping directly into battle. Mindless or simple creatures might not respond to your overtures, but more intelligent creatures may be willing to treat instead of fight, if you approach them in an appropriate manner. For example, if your adopted parent was a cloaker, when you encounter a cloaker years later, you understand the appropriate words, body language, and motions for approaching the cloaker respectfully and peacefully.

bg-feature.name: Adept Linguist
bg-feature.description: You can communicate with humanoids who don't speak any language you know. You must observe the humanoids interacting with one another for at least 1 day, after which you learn a handful of important words, expressions, and gestures - enough to communicate on a rudimentary level.

bg-feature.name: A Friend in Every Town
bg-feature.description: You have worked as a diplomat, mediator, or other form of conversationalist, and your reputation as a peacemaker precedes you, or people recognize your easy demeanor, typically allowing you to attain food and lodging at a discount. In addition, people are predisposed to warn you about dangers in a location, alert you when a threat approaches you, or seek out your help for resolving conflicts between locals.

bg-feature.name: All Eyes on You
bg-feature.description:
Your accent, mannerisms, figures of speech, and perhaps even your appearance all mark you as foreign. Curious glances are directed your way wherever you go, which can be a nuisance, but you also gain the friendly interest of scholars and others intrigued by far-off lands, to say nothing of everyday folk who are eager to hear stories of your homeland.

You can parley this attention into access to people and places you might not otherwise have, for you and your traveling companions. Noble lords, scholars, and merchant princes, to name a few, might be interested in hearing about your distant homeland and people.

bg-feature.name: Bad Reputation
bg-feature.description: No matter where you go, people are afraid of you due to your reputation. When you are in a civilized settlement, you can get away with minor criminal offenses, such as refusing to pay for food at a tavern or breaking down doors at a local shop, since most people will not report your activity to the authorities.

bg-feature.name: By Popular Demand
bg-feature.description: You can always find a place to perform, usually in an inn or tavern but possibly with a circus, at a theater, or even in a noble's court. At such a place, you receive free lodging and food of a modest or comfortable standard (depending on the quality of the establishment), as long as you perform each night. In addition, your performance makes you something of a local figure. When strangers recognize you in a town where you have performed, they typically take a liking to you.

bg-feature.name: City Secrets
bg-feature.description: You know the secret patterns and flow to cities and can find passages through the urban sprawl that others would miss. When you are not in combat, you (and companions you lead) can travel between any two locations in the city twice as fast as your speed would normally allow.

bg-feature.name: Court Functionary
bg-feature.description: Your knowledge of how bureaucracies function lets you gain access to the records and inner workings of any noble court or government you encounter. You know who the movers and shakers are, whom to go to for the favors you seek, and what the current intrigues of interest in the group are.

bg-feature.name: Criminal Contact
bg-feature.description: You have a reliable and trustworthy contact who acts as your liaison to a network of other criminals. You know how to get messages to and from your contact, even over great distances; specifically, you know the local messengers, corrupt caravan masters, and seedy sailors who can deliver messages for you.

bg-feature.name: Deep Delver
bg-feature.description: You have a knack for making your way in the deep places of the world. You can recall the twists and turns of passageways and tunnels such that you can always retrace your steps underground. You're also well acquainted with foraging and survival in the Underdark, and can determine when sources of food and water are safe to consume. You can always find sufficient food and water for yourself and up to five other people in the Underdark, as long as sustenance is available in the area.

bg-feature.name: Discovery
bg-feature.description:
The quiet seclusion of your extended hermitage gave you access to a unique and powerful discovery. The exact nature of this revelation depends on the nature of your seclusion. It might be a great truth about the cosmos, the deities, the powerful beings of the outer planes, or the forces of nature. It could be a site that no one else has ever seen. You might have uncovered a fact that has long been forgotten, or unearthed some relic of the past that could rewrite history. It might be information that would be damaging to the people who or consigned you to exile, and hence the reason for your return to society.

Work with your DM to determine the details of your discovery and its impact on the campaign.

bg-feature.name: Down Low
bg-feature.description: You are acquainted with a network of smugglers who are willing to help you out of tight situations. While in a particular town, city, or other similarly sized community (DM's discretion), you and your companions can stay for free in safe houses. Safe houses provide a poor lifestyle. While staying at a safe house, you can choose to keep your presence (and that of your companions) a secret.

bg-feature.name: Ear to the Ground
bg-feature.description: You are in frequent contact with people in the segment of society that your chosen quarries move through. These people might be associated with the criminal underworld, the rough-and-tumble folk of the streets, or members of high society. This connection comes in the form of a contact in any city you visit, a person who provides information about the people and places of the local area.

bg-feature.name: Echoes of Victory
bg-feature.description: You have attracted admiration among the people in the region that hosted your past victories. When visiting any settlement within 100 miles of where you grew up, there is a 50 percent chance you can find someone there who admires you and is willing to provide information and temporary shelter.

bg-feature.name: False Identity
bg-feature.description: You have created a second identity that includes documentation, established acquaintances, and disguises that allow you to assume that persona. Additionally, you can forge documents including official papers and personal letters, as long as you have seen an example of the kind of document or the handwriting you are trying to copy.

bg-feature.name: A Friendly Face in Every Port
bg-feature.description: Your reputation precedes you. Whenever you visit a port city, you can always find someone who knows of (or has sailed on) your former ship and is familiar with its captain and crew. They are willing to provide you and your traveling companions with a roof over your head, a bed for the night, and a decent meal. If you have a reputation for cruelty and savagery, your host is probably afraid of you and will be keen for you to leave as soon as possible. Otherwise, you receive a warm welcome, and your host keeps your presence a secret, if needed. They may also provide you with useful information about recent goings-on in the city, including which ships have been in and out of port.

bg-feature.name: Forester
bg-feature.description: Your experience living, hunting, and foraging in the woods gives you a wealth of experience to draw upon when you are traveling within a forest. If you spend an hour observing, examining, and exploring your surroundings while in a forest, you are able to identify a safe location to rest. The area is protected from all but the most extreme elements and from the nonmagical native beasts of the forest. In addition, you are able to find sufficient kindling for a small fire throughout the night.

bg-feature.name: Guild Membership
bg-feature.description:
As an established and respected member of a guild, you can rely on certain benefits that membership provides. Your fellow guild members will provide you with lodging and food if necessary, and pay for your funeral if needed. In some cities and towns, a guildhall offers a central place to meet other members of your profession, which can be a good place to meet potential patrons, allies, or hirelings.

Guilds often wield tremendous political power. If you are accused of a crime, your guild will support you if a good case can be made for your innocence or the crime is justifiable. You can also gain access to powerful political figures through the guild, if you are a member in good standing. Such connections might require the donation of money or magic items to the guild's coffers.

You must pay dues of 5 gp per month to the guild. If you miss payments, you must make up back dues to remain in the guild's good graces.

bg-feature.name: Harvest the Water
bg-feature.description: You gain advantage on ability checks made using fishing tackle. If you have access to a body of water that sustains marine life, you can maintain a moderate lifestyle while working as a fisher, and you can catch enough food to feed yourself and up to ten other people each day.

bg-feature.name: Heart of Darkness
bg-feature.description: Those who look into your eyes can see that you have faced unimaginable horror and that you are no stranger to darkness. Though they might fear you, commoners will extend you every courtesy and do their utmost to help you. Unless you have shown yourself to be a danger to them, they will even take up arms to fight alongside you, should you find yourself facing an enemy alone.

bg-feature.name: Historical Knowledge
bg-feature.description: When you enter a ruin or dungeon, you can correctly ascertain its original purpose and determine its builders, whether those were dwarves, elves, humans, yuan-ti, or some other known race. In addition, you can determine the monetary value of art objects more than a century old.

bg-feature.name: House Connection
bg-feature.description: As an agent of your house, you can always get food and lodging for yourself and your friends at a house enclave. When the house assigns you a mission, it will usually provide you with the necessary supplies and transportation. Beyond this, you have many old friends, mentors, and rivals in your house, and you may encounter one of them when you interact with a house business. The degree to which such acquaintances are willing to help you depends on your current standing in your house.

bg-feature.name: Inheritance
bg-feature.description:
You have inherited something from your family. Work with your DM to determine your inheritance: Why is your inheritance so important, and what is its full story? You might prefer for the DM to invent these details as part of the game, allowing you to learn more about your inheritance as your character does.

The DM is free to use your inheritance as a story hook, sending you on quests to learn more about its history or true nature, or confronting you with foes who want to claim it for themselves or prevent you from learning what you seek. The DM also determines the properties of your inheritance and how they figure into the item's history and importance. For instance, the object might be a minor magic item, or one that begins with a modest ability and increases in potency with the passage of time. Or, the true nature of your inheritance might not be apparent at first and is revealed only when certain conditions are met.

bg-feature.name: Knightly Regard
bg-feature.description:
You receive shelter and succor from members of your knightly order and those who are sympathetic to its aims. If your order is a religious one, you can gain aid from temples and other religious communities of your deity. Knights of civic orders can get help from the community - whether a lone settlement or a great nation that they serve, and knights of philosophical orders can find help from those they have aided in pursuit of their ideals, and those who share those ideals.

This help comes in the form of shelter and meals, and healing when appropriate, as well as occasionally risky assistance, such as a band of local citizens rallying to aid a sorely pressed knight in a fight, or those who support the order helping to smuggle a knight out of town when he or she is being hunted unjustly.

bg-feature.name: Legal Authority
bg-feature.description: You have the authority to enforce the laws of the land, and that status inspires a certain amount of respect and even fear in the populace. People mind their manners in your presence and avoid drawing your attention: they assume you have the right to be wherever you are. If you abuse this privilege, though, you can get in serious trouble with your superiors and even be stripped of your position.

bg-feature.name: Legalese
bg-feature.description: Your experience with your local legal system has given you a firm knowledge of the ins and outs of that system. Even when the law is not on your side, you can use complex terms like ex injuria jus non oritur and cogitationis poenam nemo patitur to frighten people into thinking you know what you're talking about. With common folks who don't know any better, you might be able to intimidate or deceive to get favors or special treatment.

bg-feature.name: Legion Station
bg-feature.description: You have an established place in the hierarchy of a large military force. You can requisition simple equipment for temporary use, and you can gain access to any garrison of your military, where you can rest in safety and receive the attention of medics.

bg-feature.name: Leverage
bg-feature.description: You can exert leverage over one or more individuals below you in the guild's hierarchy and demand their help as needs warrant. For example, you can have a message carried across a neighborhood, procure a short carriage ride without paying, or have others clean up a bloody mess you left in an alley. The DM decides if your demands are reasonable and if there are subordinates available to fulfill them. As your status in the guild improves, you gain influence over more people, including ones in greater positions of power.

bg-feature.name: Library Access
bg-feature.description:
Though others must often endure extensive interviews and significant fees to gain access to even the most common archives in your library, you have free and easy access to the majority of the library, though it might also have repositories of lore that are too valuable, magical, or secret to permit anyone immediate access.

You have a working knowledge of your cloister's personnel and bureaucracy, and you know how to navigate those connections with some ease.

Additionally, you are likely to gain preferential treatment at other libraries across the Realms, as professional courtesy shown to a fellow scholar.

bg-feature.name: Medical Professional
bg-feature.description: Your medical experience is always in demand.  In towns and cities, military encampments, remote lodges, and other gatherings of people, you can usually find work administering aid to those who need it.  This work keeps you fed and clothes, in a manner reflecting the wealth of your patients.  It is also an excellent way of getting to know the locals and the area.

bg-feature.name: Mercenary Life
bg-feature.description: You know the mercenary life as only someone who has experienced it can. You are able to identify mercenary companies by their emblems, and you know a little about any such company, including the names and reputations of its commanders and leaders, and who has hired them recently. You can find the taverns and festhalls where mercenaries abide in any area, as long as you speak the language. You can find mercenary work between adventures sufficient to maintain a comfortable lifestyle.

bg-feature.name: Military Rank
bg-feature.description: You have a military rank from your career as a soldier. Soldiers loyal to your former military organization still recognize your authority and influence, and they defer to you if they are of a lower rank. You can invoke your rank to exert influence over other soldiers and requisition simple equipment or horses for temporary use. You can also usually gain access to friendly military encampments and fortresses where your rank is recognized.

bg-feature.name: Name Dropping
bg-feature.description: You know and have met any number of powerful people across the land - and some of them might even remember you. You might be able to wrangle minor assistance from a major figure in the campaign, at the DM's discretion. Additionally, the common folk treat you with deference, and your heritage and the stories you tell might be good for a free meal or a place to sleep.

bg-feature.name: Never Tell Me the Odds
bg-feature.description: Odds and probability are your bread and butter. During downtime activities that involve games of chance or figuring odds on the best plan, you can get a solid sense of which choice is likely the best one and which opportunities seem too good to be true, at the DM's determination.

bg-feature.name: Nomad
bg-feature.description:
Living in the open desert has allowed your body to adapt to a range of environmental conditions. You can survive on 1 gallon of water in hot conditions (or half a gallon in normal conditions) without being forced to make Constitution saving throws, and you are considered naturally adapted to hot climates.

While in a desert, you can read the environment to predict natural weather patterns and temperatures for the next 24 hours, allowing you to cross dangerous terrain at the best times. The accuracy of your predictions is up to the GM, but they should be reliable unless affected by magic or unforeseeable events, such as distant earthquakes or volcanic eruptions.

bg-feature.name: Official Inquiry
bg-feature.description: You're experienced at gaining access to people and places to get the information you need. Through a combination of fast-talking, determination, and official-looking documentation, you can gain access to a place or an individual related to a crime you're investigating. Those who aren't involved in your investigation avoid impeding you or pass along your requests. Additionally, local law enforcement has firm opinions about you, viewing you as either a nuisance or one of their own.

bg-feature.name: Old Friends and Enemies
bg-feature.description: Your previous career as an adventurer might have been brief or long. Either way, you certainly journeyed far and met people along the way. Some of these acquaintances might remember you fondly for aiding them in their time of need. On the other hand, others may be suspicious, or even hostile, because of your past actions. When you least expect it, or maybe just when you need it, you might encounter someone who knows you from your previous adventuring career. These people work in places high and low, their fortunes varying widely. The individual responds appropriately based on your mutual history, helping or hindering you at the GM's discretion.

bg-feature.name: Position of Privilege
bg-feature.description: Thanks to your noble birth, people are inclined to think the best of you. You are welcome in high society, and people assume you have the right to be wherever you are. The common folk make every effort to accommodate you and avoid your displeasure, and other people of high birth treat you as a member of the same social sphere. You can secure an audience with a local noble if you need to.

bg-feature.name: Researcher
bg-feature.description: When you attempt to learn or recall a piece of lore, if you do not know that information, you often know where and from whom you can obtain it. Usually, this information comes from a library, scriptorium, university, or a sage or other learned person or creature. Your DM might rule that the knowledge you seek is secreted away in an almost inaccessible place, or that it simply cannot be found. Unearthing the deepest secrets of the multiverse can require an adventure or even a whole campaign.

bg-feature.name: Respect of the Stout Folk
bg-feature.description: As well respected as clan crafters are among outsiders, no one esteems them quite so highly as dwarves do. You always have free room and board in any place where shield dwarves or gold dwarves dwell, and the individuals in such a settlement might vie among themselves to determine who can offer you (and possibly your compatriots) the finest accommodations and assistance.

bg-feature.name: Retainers
bg-feature.description: You have the service of three retainers loyal to your family. These retainers can be attendants or messengers, and one might be a majordomo. Your retainers are commoners who can perform mundane tasks for you, but they do not fight for you, will not follow you into obviously dangerous areas (such as dungeons), and will leave if they are frequently endangered or abused.

bg-feature.name: Rubblebelt Refuge
bg-feature.description: You are intimately familiar with areas of the city that most people shun: ruined neighborhoods where wurms rampaged, overgrown parks that no hand has tended in decades, and the vast, sprawling rubblebelts of broken terrain that civilized folk have long abandoned. You can find a suitable place for you and your allies to hide or rest in these areas. In addition, you can find food and fresh water in these areas for yourself and up to five other people each day.

bg-feature.name: Rustic Hospitality
bg-feature.description: Since you come from the ranks of the common folk, you fit in among them with ease. You can find a place to hide, rest, or recuperate among other commoners, unless you have shown yourself to be a danger to them. They will shield you from the law or anyone else searching for you, though they will not risk their lives for you.

bg-feature.name: Safe Haven
bg-feature.description: As a faction agent, you have access to a secret network of supporters and operatives who can provide assistance on your adventures. You know a set of secret signs and passwords you can use to identify such operatives, who can provide you with access to a hidden safe house, free room and board, or assistance in finding information. These agents never risk their lives for you or risk revealing their true identities.

bg-feature.name: Servant's Invisibility
bg-feature.description: The art of excellent service requires a balance struck between being always available and yet unobtrusive, and you've mastered it. If you don't perform a visible action, speak or be spoken to, or otherwise have attention drawn to you, people nearby have trouble remembering you are even in the room.  Until you speak, perform a visible action, or have someone draw attention to you, they tend to conduct themselves as though you aren't present.

bg-feature.name: Shelter the Faithful
bg-feature.description:
You command the respect of those who share your faith, and you can perform the religious ceremonies of your deity. You and your adventuring companions can expect to receive free healing and care at a temple, shrine, or other established presence of your faith, though you must provide any material components needed for spells. Those who share your religion will support you (but only you) at a modest lifestyle.

You might also have ties to a specific temple dedicated to your chosen deity or pantheon, and you have a residence there. This could be the temple where you used to serve, if you remain on good terms with it, or a temple where you have found a new home. While near your temple, you can call upon the priests for assistance, provided the assistance you ask for is not hazardous and you remain in good standing with your temple.

bg-feature.name: Ship's Passage
bg-feature.description: When you need to, you can secure free passage on a sailing ship for yourself and your adventuring companions. You might sail on the ship you served on, or another ship you have good relations with (perhaps one captained by a former crewmate). Because you're calling in a favor, you can't be certain of a schedule or route that will meet your every need. Your DM will determine how long it takes to get where you need to go. In return for your free passage, you and your companions are expected to assist the crew during the voyage.

bg-feature.name: Supply Chain
bg-feature.description: From your time as a merchant, you retain connections with wholesalers, suppliers, and other merchants and entrepreneurs. You can call upon these connections when looking for items or information.

bg-feature.name: The Family Name
bg-feature.description: Your family name is well known in the close-knit world of nobles. Nobility and aristocrats readily recognize your name and will provide food, drink, and shelter with pleasure or out of fear, depending upon your family's reputation. You can also gain access to friendly military encampments, fortresses, or powerful political figures through your contacts among the nobles. Utilizing such connections might require the donation of money, magic items, or a great deal of drink.

bg-feature.name: Tribal Heritage
bg-feature.description:
You have an excellent knowledge of not only your tribe's territory, but also the terrain and natural resources of the rest of the North. You are familiar enough with any wilderness area that you find twice as much food and water as you normally would when you forage there.

Additionally, you can call upon the hospitality of your people, and those folk allied with your tribe, often including members of druid circles, tribes of nomadic elves, the Harpers, and the priesthoods devoted to the gods of the First Circle.

bg-feature.name: Unexepected Acquantaintence
bg-feature.description: Even though you can't recall them, someone from your past will recognize you and offer to aid you — or to impede you. The person and their relationship to you depend on the truth of your backstory. They might be a childhood friend, a former rival, or even your child who's grown up with dreams of finding their missing parent. They may want you to return to your former life even if it means abandoning your current goals and companions. Work with your GM to determine the details of this character and your history with them.

bg-feature.name: Urban Infrastructure
bg-feature.description: You have a basic knowledge of the structure of buildings, including the stuff behind the walls. You can also find blueprints of a specific building in order to learn the details of its construction. Such blueprints might provide knowledge of entry points, structural weaknesses, or secret spaces. Your access to such information isn't unlimited, though.

bg-feature.name: Wanderer
bg-feature.description: You have an excellent memory for maps and geography, and you can always recall the general layout of terrain, settlements, and other features around you. In addition, you can find food and fresh water for yourself and up to five other people each day, provided that the land offers berries, small game, water, and so forth.

bg-feature.name: Watcher's Eye
bg-feature.description: Your experience in enforcing the law, and dealing with lawbreakers, gives you a feel for local laws and criminals. You can easily find the local outpost of the watch or a similar organization, and just as easily pick out the dens of criminal activity in a community, although you're more likely to be welcome in the former locations rather than the latter.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Agony
blood-rite.description:
As a bonus action, you can invoke this rite to force a creature that you can see within 30 feet to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed saving throw, it has disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity ability checks and saving throws, and it takes necrotic damage equal to one roll of your Rite Die each time it attacks.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, the effects last for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Anxiety
blood-rite.description:
As a bonus action, you can invoke this Rite and curse one creature you can see within 30 feet of you, making it susceptible to outside influence. Until the end of your next turn, creatures that target that creature with a Charisma ability check do so with advantage.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, the creatures has disadvantage on the next Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw it makes before the end of your next turn.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Binding
blood-rite.description:
As a bonus action, you can invoke this Rite and force a Large or smaller creature that you can see within 30 feet to make a Strength saving throw. On a failed saving throw, its speed is reduced to 0 and it can't use reactions until the end of your next turn.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do, you can target any creature, and the effects last for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Blindness
blood-rite.description:
When a creature you can see within 30 feet makes an attack roll, you can use your reaction to subtract one roll of your Rite Die from its attack roll. You can invoke this Rite after the creature rolls, but before you know if its attack hits or misses the target.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do, it must subtract one roll of your Rite Die from all attack rolls until the start of your next turn.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Confusion
blood-rite.description:
As a bonus action, you can invoke this Rite and curse one creature you can see within 30 feet that is concentrating on a spell. The first time the creature makes a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration before the end of your next turn, it has disadvantage on its saving throw.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, the target has disadvantage on every Constitution saving throw it makes to maintain its concentration before the end of your next turn.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Revelation
blood-rite.description:
As a bonus action, you can invoke this Rite and choose one creature you can see within 30 feet. You immediately learn of one damage resistance, immunity, or vulnerability that the creature has. If it has none of the traits above, the DM can instead reveal one of the creature's abilities of their choice.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do, you can choose one immunity the creature has and turn it into a resistance, or one resistance the creature has and dispel it. This effecgt lasts for 1 minute.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Corrosion
blood-rite.description:
As a bonus action on your turn, you can invoke this Rite and force one creature you can see within 30 feet to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it is poisoned for 1 minute. The creature can repeat its saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, the creature remains poisoned until it succeeds on its saving throw, and each time it fails it takes necrotic damage equal to two rolls of your Rite Die.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Exposure
blood-rite.description:
When a creature within 30 feet of you takes damage, you can use your reaction to invoke this Rite and suppress any damage resistances it has until the end of your next turn.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If so do so, you also suppress any damage immunities it has, causing them to function as resistances until the end of your next turn.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Marking
blood-rite.description:
As a bonus action, you can invoke this Rite and mark a target you can see within 30 feet. Until the end of your next turn, all weapon attacks you make againt that target have advantage.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, any weapon attacks you make against that target score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20 on the d20 until the end of your next turn.

blood-rite.name: Rite of the Puppet
blood-rite.description:
When a creature you can see within 30 feet is reduced to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to invoke this Rite and have the creature make a single weapon attack against a creature of your choice within its reach.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, you can force the creature to move up to its full speed and it gains a bonus to its weapon attack roll equal to one roll of your Rite Die.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Darkness
blood-rite.description:
As a bonus action, you can invoke this Rite and force one creature you can see within 30 feet to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it is blinded, deafened, and silenced for 1 minute. As an action on its turn, the target can repeat its saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, in addition to the normal effect, the creature's speed is reduced to 0 while under the effects of this Rite.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Fear
blood-rite.description:
As a bonus action, you can invoke this Rite and force a creature that can see or hear you within 30 feet to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it is frightened of your for 1 minute. While frightened in this way, the creature must take the Dash action and move away from you by the safest available route on each of its turns, unless there is nowhere to move. If it ends its turn in a location where it doesn't have line of sight to you, it can repeat its saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, a creature that fails its saving throw is stunned for the duration of the Rite, so long as it has line of sight to you. If it takes any damage, it can repeat its saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Siphoning
blood-rite.description:
As an action, you can invoke this Rite and force a creature you touch to make a Charisma saving throw as you attempt to drain its very life force. On a failed save, the target takes necrotic damage equal to three rolls of your Rite Die, and you gain temporary hit points equal to the necrotic damage dealt.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, the creature takes the maximum possible necrotic damage in place of rolling.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Decay
blood-rite.description:
As an action, you can invoke this Rite and force a creature you can see within 30 feet to make a Constitution saving throw as you corrupt the blood in their veins. The creature takes necrotic damage equal to eight rolls of your Rite Die on a failed save, and half as much damage on a success.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, this Rite ignores resistance to necrotic damage, and treats immunity as resistance. In addition, a creature reduced to 0 hit points by this Rite is killed as their body is turned into a pile of fine, flesh-colored dust.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Nightmares
blood-rite.description:
As an action, you can invoke this Rite and force a creature you can see within 30 feet to make a Wisdom saving throw as you infect its mind with nightmarish phantasms. On a failed save, the creature takes psychic damage equal to two rolls of your Rite Die and is frightened of you for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns before the Rite ends, the creature must succed on a Wisdom saving throw or take psychic damage equal to four rolls of your Rite Die. On a successful save, this Rite ends.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, the creature is incapacitated and has a speed of 0 for the duration of this Rite.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Exsanguination
blood-rite.description:
As an action, you can invoke the most powerul and ancient Rite to force one creature you can see within 30 feet to make a Constitution saving throw as you attempt to drain their body of all blood. It takes necrotic damage equal to twelve rolls of your Rite Die on a failed save, or half as much on a success. A creature that you have dealt damage to since the start of your previous turn that is not at its maximum hit points has disadvantage on this saving throw.

When you invoke this Rite, you can make a Vital Sacrifice to empower it. If you do so, this Rite ignores resistance to necrotic damage, and treats immunity as resistance. In addition, a creature reduced to 0 hit points by this Rite is killed as their body is turned into a pile of fine, flesh-colored dust.

blood-rite.name: Rite of Reaping
blood-rite.description: As an action, you can invoke this Rite, sacrifice any number of your maximum hit points, and touch a creature.  If it has a number of remaining hit points less than or equal to the hit points you sacrificed, it dies.  Otherwise, this Rite has no effect.

bound-spirit.name: Agony
bound-spirit.description: In the presence of a spirit of Agony, foes' wounds continue to bleed and fires continue to burn. While Agony is bound, when you roll damage for an attack or spell you cast, for each 1 on a damage die, you can add the level of the spirit to the damage total.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: You can release Agony as a reaction when you roll the highest possible number on a damage die. Roll a number of d6s equal to the spirit's level and add the total to the triggering damage as psychic damage.

bound-spirit.name: Desire
bound-spirit.description: Spirits of Desire impress your will onto others and enhance existing desires. Friendly and charmed creatures within 30 feet of you have disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws against your spells. Once a creature succeeds on a Wisdom saving throw against one of your spells, that creature is immune to this spirit's passive effect for 24 hours.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: When you release this spirit as a bonus action, you attempt to charm a creature you can see within 30 feet of you. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or be charmed by you for 1 minute or until it takes damage. The spirit's level determines what kind of creature can be charmed. At 3rd level and below, only humanoids and beasts are affected. At 4th level and above, all creatures can be affected.

bound-spirit.name: Empathy
bound-spirit.description: Spirits of Empathy force your enemies to share your pain. While Empathy is bound, whenever a creature deals damage to you, you can use your reaction to retaliate. The creature takes psychic damage equal to twice the spirit's level.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: You can release Empathy as a reaction whenever a creature deals damage to you or an ally within 30 feet of you. The creature takes psychic damage equal to the triggering damage + the spirit's level.

bound-spirit.name: Envy
bound-spirit.description: Spirits of Envy take from others what they covet for themselves - life. Once on each of your turns, when you damage a creature with an attack or spell while Envy is bound, you regain a number of hit points equal to the level of the spirit.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: When you deal damage to a creature with an attack or spell you can release Envy as a reaction. When you do so, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to the triggering damage.

bound-spirit.name: Fear
bound-spirit.description:
Spirits of Fear bring nightmares to life. While Fear is bound, you can add your proficiency bonus to Charisma (Intimidation) checks, or double it if you already do.

Additionally, creatures provoke opportunity attacks from you even if they take the Disengage action before leaving your reach.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: When Fear is released from its bonds as a bonus action, a number of creatures equal to the spirit's level within 30 feet of you must succeed on Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or be frightened of you for 1 minute. A frightened target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

bound-spirit.name: Generosity
bound-spirit.description: Spirits of Generosity are always willing to make sacrifices for those who bind them with good intentions. Your spells that restore hit points restore additional hit points equal to the spirit's level.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: You can release Generosity as a bonus action and gift the spirit to an ally within 30 feet of you. The spirit protects the ally, granting them a number of temporary hit points equal to 5 times the spirit's level. These temporary hit points last 10 minutes.

bound-spirit.name: Guilt
bound-spirit.description:
Spirits of Guilt cause your enemies hesitation in acts that would wrong you. While Guilt is bound, when you are attacked you can use your reaction to gain a bonus to AC against that attack equal to the level of the spirit.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to the spirit's level. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: When you release Guilt from your power as a bonus action, one creature you can see within 60 feet has disadvantage on attack rolls against you for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turn the target can make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC, ending the effect on itself on a success.

bound-spirit.name: Hate
bound-spirit.description:
Spirits of Hate inspire a ferocity in you. When you are damaged by a creature, you can choose to channel Hate and gain advantage on attack rolls against that creature until the end of your next turn.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to the spirit's level. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: When you damage a creature with an attack you can release Hate as a reaction. Roll a number of d6s equal to the spirit's level and add the total to the triggering damage as necrotic damage.

bound-spirit.name: Humility
bound-spirit.description: When you make an ability check with which you are not proficient at disadvantage, the result can not be lower than 8 + the level of this spirit.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: As a reaction when a creature you can see makes a saving throw or ability check, you can release Humility from your power to bestow it upon the creature. Add the spirit's level to the roll. You can do so after the roll, but must decide before the DM says whether the roll succeeds or fails.

bound-spirit.name: Hunger
bound-spirit.description: Spirits of Hunger sustain their binder and deprive their enemies of energy. While Hunger is bound you require no food or water.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: You can release Hunger as a bonus action to exhaust a number of creatures within 30 feet of you equal to the spirit's level. A target gains one level of exhaustion, and cannot be affected by a Spirit of Hunger for 24 hours.

bound-spirit.name: Passion
bound-spirit.description:
Spirits of Passion give those who bind them the power to push themselves and others to greater heights of success. While this spirit is bound you can channel Passion when you make an attack roll, ability check or saving throw, or when an ally within 30 feet of you does, you roll a d6 and add the number rolled to the total.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to the spirit's level. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. You lose all remaining dice when you release Passion.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description:
You can release Passion as a reaction when you make an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw. You gain advantage on the roll.

Additionally, you and each friendly creature within 30 feet of you gain a d6 that lasts until the end of your next turn. A creature can expend and roll the d6 when they make an attack roll or ability check, adding it to the total.

bound-spirit.name: Pride
bound-spirit.description: Creatures in your presence are more easily filled with a dangerous sense of pride, oversight, and overconfidence. When you make an ability check that is contested by a creature you can see, you gain a bonus to the ability check equal to the spirit's level.

subFeatures.name: Release
subFeatures.description: When a creature you can see succeeds on an attack roll or ability check, you can release Pride as a reaction to curse that creature to a disgraceful fall. The next time the target makes an attack roll or ability check, it does so with disadvantage, and subtracts the spirit's level from the total.

bound-spirit.name: Serenity
bound-spirit.description:
Spirits of Serenity bring peace and clarity of thought to those who bind them. You don't need to sleep. Instead, you can meditate deeply, remaining semiconscious, for 4 hours a day. After resting in this way, you gain the same benefit that a human does from 8 hours of sleep.
